_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
AES Deepwater has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested an accident prevention such as employee training, safety in design, installation, operations and ongoing maintenance of the processes.

Description of stationary sources and regulated substances
AES Deepwater is located in Pasadena Texas and operates a petroleum coke fired were for the generation of electricity. In 2004 Deepwater sent in a De-registration letter when ammonia was removed when the fertilizer process was shutdown. In 2007 ammonia will become part of our process. The ammonia is part of a scrubbing agent to be used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) System to help reduce emissions.

General accidental release prevention program / chemical specific prevention
AES Deepwater provides for and encourages all of its employees to anticipate and all facets of the risk management plan as well as process safety management.  Deepwater also provides a variety of technical procedures there used to maintain a safe operating environment and chemical handling.

Five-year accident history
Ammonia was last used at AES Deepwater in 1999 and was removed from the site and 2004. In that time period no releases are events have occurred in the use of ammonia. Every incident is investigated to determine ?root cause? and to prevent similar incidents from reoccurring.

Emergency response program
AES Deepwater works closely with the Pasadena LEPC to protect workers, public safety and the environment. Coordination includes periodic meetings with the LEPC. The LEPC is Deepwater will communicate its risk management plan to the public.
